pageContext.claim: “So the deal was made and it was made for a lot of money. I think it was $5.7 billion or $5.6 billion. Now in all fairness, it's two planes and there's a lot of stuff in those planes I won't talk to you about. So, I told Boeing -- the head of Boeing, they said, sir, please. We'd like to get started in the planes. I said, I do too, but I'm not paying $5.6 billion and I'm not paying $4.6 billion. I said, it has to have a three on the front of it. That's a hell of a lot of money too, but it is a rather complex situation....They came back at $4 billion. That's a lot of money. But I save like $1.6 billion or $1.7 billion, nobody wants to talk about it. Nobody wants to talk about it.”
pageContext.analysis: No one talks about it because he did not save this money. Shortly before he took the oath of office, Trump tweeted he would not pay $4 billion to replace the aircraft used for Air Force One. (The actual costs had not been set.) Then he struck a deal supposedly for $3.9 billion. "However, once all costs are included — such as buying a new hangar for the aircraft and the base cost of the 747s themselves — the Air Force will pay $5.3 billion," according to Defense One. Just the instruction manuals will cost $84 million.
